image.altText: Keppel MP Brittany Lauga

props.synopsis: Queensland police have confirmed they are investigating a sexual assault complaint relating to an incident in Yeppoon last Sunday.

title.children: Queensland MP Brittany Lauga allegedly drugged and sexually assaulted on a night out

image.altText: Callum and Jake smiling and holding a dog.

props.synopsis: Mexican authorities say three bodies have been found in an area where two Australian brothers and their American travel companion are missing. The bodies have not been identified.

title.children: Bodies found in Mexico's north-west after Australian brothers disappear

image.altText: Danniel Lyon in an army uniform holding his son and his wife Caitland in a white jumper holding a baby

props.synopsis: The final moments of the four victims are revealed for the first time at an inquiry investigating what went wrong in the fatal MRH-90 crash during a training exercise.

title.children: Caitland’s husband died in the Taipan helicopter crash. She was told she'd find someone new

image.altText: Stag De looze

props.synopsis: Former staff at a Portland strip club have accused its Australian owner of failing to act on complaints of sexual harassment and assault by a manager who now faces criminal charges.

title.children: Australian doctor's strip club in the US embroiled in workplace investigation

image.altText: Mugshot of a young man with dark hair and brown eyes.

props.synopsis: Bonza's US private equity backers, 777 Partners, is fighting financial and legal fires around the world with its portfolio of budget airlines and financially struggling football clubs.

title.children: The mysterious man behind 777 Partners, the strange private equity firm that owns Bonza

image.altText: A 3D-printed Google logo sits on an Apple Macbook laptop

props.synopsis: Google and Apple are being dragged through the courts around the world and the case has finally hit Australia. Courtrooms have heard how the tech giants are quietly earning billions in commissions from smartphone users. Here’s what could happen if they lose the fight here.

title.children: The biggest tech court case in Australian history you've never heard of

image.altText: A group of soldiers standing at the belly of an open plane

props.synopsis: The West has taken to parachuting food aid into Gaza to help feed the people below. But on the ground, these meagre packages have sometimes turned deadly.

title.children: The West is taking elaborate measures to get food into Gaza. Why is the obvious solution not an option?

image.altText: out of focus women's hair looking at a red roof, beige weatherboard home with empty yard

props.synopsis: A family who bought a home in regional Victoria without seeing it in person say they have been cleaning for a month but can't live in it because of its vile state.

title.children: 'Vomited in the street': Home buyer opens door to disgusting mess after online purchase

image.altText: An unidentifiable woman with her head in her hands.

props.synopsis: Edwina lives with her two children in a quiet Perth street, but what makes her house different is the panic room with a window that can only be broken from the inside.

title.children: A panic room and four locks on each door. The reality of living in fear of a violent ex-partner

image.altText: Anthony Albanese frowns while wearing a suit, tie, and pink ribbon on his lapel

props.synopsis: The question now for all politicians is how to ensure the momentum to properly address at least some of the issues fuelling the gendered violence crisis continues.

title.children: There is so much to be done to combat the gendered violence crisis. Here are a few places the government could start

image.altText: A streetscape in Baja California, with power poles and a graffitied wall

props.synopsis: Baja California is known for its world-class surf and luxury resorts, but statistics show it's become one of the most dangerous places in the country.

title.children: Beyond its luxury resorts and world-class surf, a war is being waged in Baja California

image.altText: Andrew Tate is escorted in handcuffs by a balaclava-clad police officer from a court building

props.synopsis: As this country anguishes about how to stop the horrifying level of targeted male violence against women, men must step in to prevent toxic misogynists like Andrew Tate from infecting young minds.

title.children: Andrew Tate and his ilk have already infected the minds of our young men, but it's not too late

image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: The major banks and mortgage brokers are calling for regulations on lending to be wound back to make it easier to give people homes loans, but consumer groups say this is dangerous amid a spike in cases of mortgage hardship.

title.children: 'You have to be rich to get a loan': Big bank bosses say too much regulation is locking many Australians out of home ownership

image.altText: An illustration of a swan looking longingly down into an empty nest.

props.synopsis: While a significant portion of parents are sad to see their children fly the nest, it does not have to be all bad.

title.children: Parents suffering from empty nest syndrome 'not alone' experts say

image.altText: A man on a poster wearing a turban.

props.synopsis: Canadian police say the murder of the Sikh separatist leader is still under investigation and they are probing possible links to the Indian government.

title.children: Three men arrested and charged with the murder of Sikh leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar

image.altText: Photo of women holding glasses of wine, taken from above.

props.synopsis: House parties in Australia have looked the same way for years, but the rise of inner-city living may be changing how we hang out for good.

title.children: For some in Australia's apartment generation, house parties are off limits

image.altText: People holding signs objecting to violence against women.

props.synopsis: A shelter north of Sydney says the number of vulnerable women and children who need their service has tripled in the past three years, but funding hasn't kept up with demand, writes Lia Harris.

title.children: Domestic violence campaigners agree there is one key thing all frontline services need to help protect women

props.synopsis: A fresh crisis has hit the beleaguered Snowy 2.0 hydropower project, with part of a tunnel collapsing and boring machine "Florence" once again struggling to progress through difficult geological terrain.

title.children: Partial tunnel collapse at Snowy 2.0 construction site raises fresh safety concerns

image.altText: A seal in an enclosure with a small electronic device on its head.

props.synopsis: There is no denying his roly-poly appeal — but the return of the southern elephant seal nicknamed "Neil" to dry land in Tasmania has prompted experts to plead yet again that if the public don't stay clear, there could be dire consequences.

title.children: 'Neil the seal' is back — with authorities pleading for commonsense from human fans

image.altText: Under clear blue water a diver in flippers, back wetsuit and snorkle, swims close to reef covered in a yellow frame.

props.synopsis: Australian scientists are trying to boost coral regrowth. Experiments broadcasting sounds from healthy coral reefs are helping them.

title.children: How an underwater boombox and a science experiment could help our endangered coral reefs

image.altText: Leslie Jamison sits in a pink chair looking at the camera. She has one arm resting on the seat back.

props.synopsis: Leslie Jamison's new memoir Splinters is released in Australia next week as the bestselling American author visits Australia for the Melbourne Writers Festival.

title.children: Leslie Jamison has been compared with Joan Didion and Helen Garner. Her new book tackles motherhood

image.altText: A man at podium smiles at the camera in front of five more men behind a long table.

props.synopsis: In a film landscape bloated with product origin stories, Unfrosted, the farcical story of the invention of Pop-Tart, had the potential to be great. If only it wasn't for Jerry Seinfeld.

title.children: Jerry Seinfeld's new comedy would be great — if it wasn't for Jerry Seinfeld

image.altText: three women looking at the camera

props.synopsis: In the fight for the survival of Torres Strait’s islands climate change looms large, but has the Australian government failed to protect them? A judge will make a ruling after a landmark Federal Court case wrapped up this week.

title.children: Climate change is changing their island home, but whose fault is it? A judge will decide

image.altText: A woman’s hands holding a smartphone, surrounded by messages of upset emojis

props.synopsis: If you've lived online long enough for Facebook to start dredging up embarrassing status updates from a decade ago, chances are you've picked up on a distinct vibe shift in our virtual world.

title.children: 'People don't know where to go': Why social media feels so different right now, and where it's all heading

image.altText: Close-up of Tasmania Devils AFL team foundation jumper design.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's JackJumpers have shown small market sporting success can be achieved in Australia, but history is littered with cautionary tales for the AFL's newest franchise to avoid.

title.children: Has Tasmania found the blueprint for expansion club sporting glory?

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The teenage boy who inflicted the fatal wound after breaking into the North Lakes home in 2022, pleaded guilty to her murder earlier this year and faced a sentencing hearing in Brisbane on Friday.

title.children: Video of Emma Lovell being stabbed to death at her home played in court in front of family

image.altText: Man wearing cap and grey t-shirt standing in front of electric ovens

props.synopsis: Complex tariffs supposed to help make the grid more efficient have backfired badly for Cameron Boscacci's business, sparking a radical move to save him thousands on peak power charges.

title.children: Why this baker ripped out his electric stove to avoid thousands in power 'penalties'

image.altText: AFL coach Craig McRae, in a black shirt, walking off a football field

props.synopsis: After Collingwood pulled off another thrilling win, Magpies coach Craig McRae opened his press conference to declare "enough is enough" as the AFL condemns gender-based violence.

title.children: Collingwood coach Craig McRae gives powerful speech against gender-based violence

image.altText: A woman wearing a black top holding a baby while sitting on a couch

props.synopsis: From cash payments and extended parental leave to subsidised education, some of Asia's largest economies are spending millions to try to get people to have children and reverse declining fertility rates.

title.children: This is how countries in Asia are trying to convince people to have kids

image.altText: Katrine Hildyard looks at the camera in a dark room

props.synopsis: SA's child protection minister orders a review of cases involving the removal of newborn babies from their mothers at public birthing hospitals, following damning whistleblower claims of "inhumane" practices.

title.children: 'Heartbreaking' newborn removals at public birthing hospitals trigger review

image.altText: Fractional cover map of Australia

props.synopsis: Satellite data impressively illustrates what many northern Australian producers savouring lush pasture already know — the just-finished wet season was one for the record books.

title.children: Grass monitoring from space reveals extent of phenomenal wet season

image.altText: Two young female office workers take selfies while wearing comfortable casual clothes.

props.synopsis: Young office workers in China are rebelling against traditional workplace demands to dress up by wearing casual clothes as part of a popular social media trend known as "wear a gross outfit to work".

title.children: 'Is my outfit gross enough?' Young professionals in China are rebelling by 'dressing down' at work
